course.title: American History II
course.subtitle: 1865 to Present
course.description: Survey of American history from Reconstruction to the present, emphasizing social, political, economic development, and America's emergence as a global power.

clos.text: Analyze the transformation of American society from agricultural to industrial to post-industrial economy (1865-present)
Evaluate how diverse groups struggled for civil rights and inclusion
Apply historical thinking skills to interpret primary and secondary sources about modern America
Communicate historical arguments about contemporary issues through historical analysis

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Source Analysis
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Distinguish primary from secondary sources, evaluate credibility, identify bias

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Chronological Reasoning
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Sequence events, identify cause-effect relationships, understand periodization

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Contextualization
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Situate events within broader historical, geographic, and cultural contexts

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Comparison
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Compare historical developments across time, space, and groups

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Data Literacy
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Interpret quantitative historical evidence (charts, graphs, maps, statistics)
progression: Module 3: Progressive Era reform data analysis
Module 6: Civil Rights movement data analysis

modules.title: Reconstruction & Its Failure
inquiryQuestions: Can a nation be repaired after fracture, or must it be remade?
What happens when revolutionary promises are abandoned for political compromise?
Who defines freedom, and who has the power to take it away?

mlos.text: Analyze competing visions of Reconstruction (Presidential, Congressional, Radical) and their outcomes
Evaluate how African Americans exercised freedom during Reconstruction and resisted its rollback
Explain the political, economic, and social factors that led to Reconstruction's collapse

content.title: IC1: Presidential & Congressional Reconstruction
content.description: Lincoln's & Johnson's plans, Congressional opposition, 13th/14th/15th Amendments

content.title: IC2: Radical Reconstruction & Black Political Power
content.description: Military Reconstruction, Freedmen's Bureau, Black elected officials, land and labor

content.title: IC3: Redemption & Reconstruction's End
content.description: Southern resistance, KKK violence, Compromise of 1877, Jim Crow begins

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 key historical terms with their correct definitions. Terms include Reconstruction, Black Codes, Freedmen's Bureau, Sharecropping, and more. You have 2 attempts and 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 multiple-choice questions about key people and events from Reconstruction. You have 2 attempts and 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose between Timeline Builder (sort Reconstruction events 1865-1877) or Comparison Activity (analyze Presidential vs Congressional Reconstruction approaches). You have 2 attempts and 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Module 1 Project Checkpoint: Initial Definition + Piece #1

modules.title: Gilded Age & Industrialization
inquiryQuestions: Is industrial growth worth the human cost it demands?
How did capitalism reshape American identity and values?
Who benefited from the Gilded Age, and who was left behind?

mlos.text: Analyze the rise of industrial capitalism and its impact on workers, communities, and the environment
Evaluate labor movements, Populism, and working-class resistance to corporate power
Explain how immigration and westward expansion transformed American society and culture

content.title: IC1: Industrial Capitalism & Robber Barons
content.description: Railroad expansion, Andrew Carnegie, John D. Rockefeller, Social Darwinism, monopolies

content.title: IC2: Labor Struggles & Populism
content.description: Haymarket Affair, Homestead Strike, Pullman Strike, Knights of Labor, Populist movement

content.title: IC3: Immigration & Urban Life
content.description: New immigration, urban growth, tenements, political machines, Jim Crow solidifies

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 key terms including Gilded Age, Robber Barons, Social Darwinism, Populism, Haymarket Affair, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about key people (Andrew Carnegie, Eugene Debs, Jane Addams) and Gilded Age events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sort events 1877-1900) or Comparison (analyze winners vs losers of industrialization). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Discussion Board 1: Industrial Capitalism & Portfolio Piece #2

modules.title: Progressive Era & Empire
inquiryQuestions: Can America reform at home while expanding abroad?
What makes reform 'progressive,' and who gets left behind?
How did reformers both challenge and reinforce existing hierarchies?

mlos.text: Analyze Progressive Era reforms and their impact on democracy, labor, and social justice
Evaluate American imperialism and its consequences for the Philippines, Puerto Rico, Cuba, and Hawaii
Explain women's suffrage movement strategies and the 19th Amendment's limitations

content.title: IC1: Progressive Reforms
content.description: Muckrakers, Triangle Shirtwaist Fire, child labor laws, women's suffrage, limits of reform

content.title: IC2: American Empire
content.description: Spanish-American War, Philippine-American War, Panama Canal, Roosevelt Corollary

content.title: IC3: World War I Begins
content.description: European war origins, American neutrality, preparedness debates, path to intervention

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including Progressivism, Muckrakers, Triangle Fire, Women's Suffrage, Spanish-American War, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Theodore Roosevelt, Jane Addams, Ida B. Wells, and Progressive Era events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sequence Progressive Era events 1890-1920) or Comparison (analyze different Progressive reform strategies). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

activities.title: LA4: Analyzing Progressive Era Reform Data
activities.format: Mixed Question Types (Categorization, Hotspot, Matching, Multiple Answer, Numeric)
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze historical data from the Progressive Era including immigration trends, labor strikes, women's suffrage timeline, and child labor statistics. View 4 detailed charts and answer 10 questions using various question types. 2 attempts, 35 minutes.

assessments.title: Module 3 Project Checkpoint: Piece #3 - Progressive Reforms Map

modules.title: World War I & 1920s
inquiryQuestions: How did World War I transform America's role in the world?
What tensions defined the 1920s, and why did they remain unresolved?
Can prosperity mask inequality, and for how long?

mlos.text: Analyze World War I's impact on American society, civil liberties, and global power
Evaluate cultural conflicts of the 1920s (Red Scare, immigration restriction, Prohibition, Scopes Trial)
Explain how the Harlem Renaissance and Great Migration transformed African American life and culture

content.title: IC1: World War I & Homefront
content.description: U.S. entry, mobilization, Espionage Act, African American soldiers, Treaty of Versailles

content.title: IC2: Red Scare & Cultural Conflicts
content.description: Palmer Raids, immigration restriction, KKK revival, Prohibition, Scopes Trial

content.title: IC3: Jazz Age & Consumer Culture
content.description: Great Migration, Harlem Renaissance, consumerism, new woman, mass culture

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including WWI, Treaty of Versailles, Red Scare, Great Migration, Harlem Renaissance, Prohibition. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Woodrow Wilson, Langston Hughes, Marcus Garvey, and 1920s events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sort WWI and 1920s events 1914-1929) or Comparison (analyze cultural conflicts of the 1920s). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Discussion Board 2: Modern America & Portfolio Piece #4

modules.title: Depression & World War II
inquiryQuestions: How do crises reshape government's role and citizens' expectations?
What does 'total war' mean for democracy and civil liberties?
Who sacrificed most during the Depression and World War II?

mlos.text: Analyze the causes and consequences of the Great Depression and New Deal programs
Evaluate World War II's impact on American society, civil liberties, and the home front
Explain how WWII positioned the United States as a global superpower

content.title: IC1: Great Depression & New Deal
content.description: Stock market crash, Hoover's response, FDR's New Deal, labor unions, critics left and right

content.title: IC2: World War II & Homefront
content.description: U.S. entry, mobilization, Japanese internment, women and African Americans in war effort

content.title: IC3: Allied Victory & America's New Role
content.description: D-Day, Pacific Theater, atomic bomb, Holocaust, United Nations, postwar planning

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including Great Depression, New Deal, Pearl Harbor, Japanese Internment, D-Day, atomic bomb. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Franklin D. Roosevelt, Eleanor Roosevelt, and WWII events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sequence Depression and WWII events 1929-1945) or Comparison (analyze New Deal vs wartime government expansion). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Module 5 Project Checkpoint: Piece #5 - Government & Citizen Sacrifice

modules.title: Cold War & Civil Rights
inquiryQuestions: Can America promote democracy abroad while denying it at home?
What makes a social movement successful, and who defines success?
Who gets to decide what is 'un-American'?

mlos.text: Analyze the origins, strategies, and global impact of the Cold War
Evaluate the strategies and achievements of the Civil Rights Movement
Explain how the Vietnam War divided American society and eroded Cold War consensus

content.title: IC1: Cold War Origins & Containment
content.description: Truman Doctrine, Marshall Plan, Korean War, McCarthyism, nuclear arms race

content.title: IC2: Civil Rights Movement
content.description: Brown v Board, Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Riders, March on Washington, Civil Rights Act 1964, Voting Rights Act 1965

content.title: IC3: Vietnam War & Social Upheaval
content.description: Vietnam escalation, antiwar movement, counterculture, 1968 turning point

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including Cold War, Containment, McCarthyism, Brown v Board, Civil Rights Act 1964, Vietnam War. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Martin Luther King Jr., Malcolm X, Rosa Parks, and Cold War events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sequence Cold War and Civil Rights events 1945-1968) or Comparison (analyze different Civil Rights strategies). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

activities.title: LA4: Analyzing Civil Rights Movement Data
activities.format: Mixed Question Types (Ordering, Multiple Answer, Categorization, Numeric, Matching)
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze historical data about Civil Rights movement including voting rights registration, desegregation timeline, legislative victories, and protest participation. View 4 detailed charts and answer 10 questions. 2 attempts, 35 minutes.

assessments.title: Discussion Board 3: Civil Rights Strategies & Portfolio Piece #6

modules.title: Rights Revolutions & Conservative Turn
inquiryQuestions: Why did rights movements expand while political culture shifted right?
What is a 'culture war,' and why does it persist?
Whose vision of America won, and at what cost?

mlos.text: Analyze the expansion of rights movements (women, LGBTQ+, Chicano, American Indian) and conservative backlash
Evaluate the Reagan Revolution and conservative movement's impact on government, economy, and culture
Explain the Watergate crisis and the erosion of trust in government institutions

content.title: IC1: Rights Revolutions & Backlash
content.description: Women's liberation, Roe v Wade, Chicano movement, AIM, Stonewall, conservative reaction

content.title: IC2: Crisis of Confidence
content.description: Watergate, Nixon resignation, Carter and malaise, Iran hostage crisis, economic stagflation

content.title: IC3: Reagan Revolution & Conservative Ascendance
content.description: Reaganomics, New Right, AIDS crisis, end of Cold War, Gulf War

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including Roe v Wade, Watergate, Reagan Revolution, AIDS Crisis, Conservative Movement, End of Cold War. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan, Gloria Steinem, and late 20th century events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sequence events 1968-1992) or Comparison (analyze liberal vs conservative visions of America). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Module 7 Final Portfolio: 'What is America?' Complete Journey

modules.title: Contemporary America
inquiryQuestions: What problems remain unresolved from earlier eras of American history?
How does history explain our present political and social divisions?
What is America becoming, and who gets to decide?

mlos.text: Analyze 9/11's impact on American foreign policy, civil liberties, and national identity
Evaluate contemporary social movements (Black Lives Matter, #MeToo, LGBTQ+ rights) in historical context
Explain the Great Recession, political polarization, and challenges of the 21st century

content.title: IC1: Post-Cold War & 9/11
content.description: Globalization, Clinton era, 9/11 attacks, War on Terror, Afghanistan and Iraq Wars

content.title: IC2: Great Recession & Obama Era
content.description: 2008 financial crisis, first Black president, Tea Party, Affordable Care Act, marriage equality

content.title: IC3: Contemporary Challenges
content.description: Political polarization, Black Lives Matter, Trump era, COVID-19 pandemic, climate change, democracy under strain

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including 9/11, Iraq War, Great Recession, Obama, Trump, COVID-19, Black Lives Matter, Climate Change. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about contemporary leaders and events from 1992 to present. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sequence contemporary events 1992-present) or Comparison (analyze continuity and change from 1865 to today). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

assessments.title: Discussion Board 4: Contemporary America & Final Reflection
